description: From Middle English avoiden, from Anglo-Norman avoider, Old French esvuidier (“to empty out”), from es- + vuidier, from Vulgar Latin *vocitāre < *vocitus < *vocivus, ultimately related to Latin vacuus. Displaced native Old English forbūgan (literally “to bend away from”).

verbs.description: avoid (third-person singular simple present avoids, present participle avoiding, simple past and past participle avoided)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To try not to meet or communicate with (a person); to shun
(transitive) To stay out of the way of (something harmful).
examples: One town was flooded from the storm, while the other town avoided the storm.

entries.meaning: to keep away from; to keep clear of; to stay away from
examples: I try to avoid the company of gamblers.

entries.meaning: To try not to do something or to have something happen
(transitive, obsolete) To make empty; to clear.
examples: If thou haue, he shal lyue with thee, and auoide thee out ; and he shal not sorewen vpon thee.

entries.meaning: (transitive, now law) To make void, to annul; to refute (especially a contract).
examples: But Y seie, this testament is confermed of God; the lawe that was maad after foure hundrid and thritti yeer, makith not the testament veyn to auoide awei the biheest.

entries.meaning: (transitive, law) To defeat or evade; to invalidate.
(transitive, obsolete) To emit or throw out; to void.
examples: […]  the citie of Memi, where is a great Caue or Denne, in the whiche is a spryng or fountayne that contynually auoydeth a great quantitie of Bitumen  […]

entries.meaning: (transitive, obsolete) To leave, evacuate; to leave as empty, to withdraw or come away from.
examples: […]  the bishop commaunded al to auoide the chambre for an houre, and beganne to talke after this manner to his chaplin  […]
Whanne Y was a litil child, Y spak as a litil child, Y vndurstood as a litil child, Y thouyte as a litil child; but whanne Y was maad a man, Y auoidide tho thingis that weren of a litil child.

entries.meaning: (intransitive, obsolete) To retire; to withdraw, depart, go away.
(intransitive, obsolete) To become void or vacant.
